text:
The ".jar" set that is produced in the line:
for i in "${ANT_LIB}"/*.jar
will skip .JAR files (uppercase .JAR).

This happened in my case in Windows under Cygwin (this was
strange because the file names in "ls" appear in lower-case
from the Cygwin shell, yet when doing "ls" within the script
they their names appeared in uppercase (??))

The following fixes this problem in Windows platforms under
Cygwin:

for i in "${ANT_LIB}"/*.jar "${ANT_LIB}"/*.JAR
# I added the last .JAR because the initial set did not include
# any uppercase .jar files
do
  # if the directory is empty, then it will return the input string
  # this is stupid, so case for it
  if [ "$i" != "${ANT_LIB}/*.jar" -a "$i" != "${ANT_LIB}/*.JAR" ] ; then
    if [ -z "$LOCALCLASSPATH" ] ; then
      LOCALCLASSPATH=$i
    else
      LOCALCLASSPATH="$i":"$LOCALCLASSPATH"
    fi
  fi
done

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Another problem with the script is unrelated to the "jar" case:

In lines 71 - 84 ANT_LIB is set before ANT_HOME for Cygwin is computed.
The statements
# set ANT_LIB location
ANT_LIB=${ANT_HOME}/lib
should go after 
# For Cygwin, ensure paths are in UNIX format before anything is touched
if $cygwin ; then
  [ -n "$ANT_HOME" ] &&
  .........snip
fi

What about jAR, jAr, jaR, JaR, Jar, JAr ? :o)

for i in "${ANT_LIB}"/*.[jJ][aA][rR]

would be better but I would need the feedback from the unix gurus out there 
and see what is the common behavior for extensions with mixed cases 
considering if it is legal or somekind of a hack to deal with a flaw.

(I'm also not sure if the regex here can be simplified with a /i to be 
insensitive match as I could not find a good reference documentation on shell 
patterns in for loop, but it does not look like so)
